ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows

Section titled “ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows”

Claude Code, Anthropic’s official CLI tool for AI-assisted development, has a powerful automation system through its .claude configuration files. However, creating complex workflows with multiple sub-agents, conditional branching, and user interactions requires editing markdown and YAML files manually. ClaudeCode Workflow Studio (cc-wf-studio) by breaking-brake brings a visual, drag-and-drop editor to VSCode, making workflow creation intuitive and accessible.

What is ClaudeCode Workflow Studio?

Section titled “What is ClaudeCode Workflow Studio?”

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio is a VSCode extension that provides a visual workflow editor for Claude Code. It allows you to:

  • Design workflows visually - Drag and drop nodes onto a canvas
  • Configure without code - Set up sub-agents, skills, and MCP tools through a UI
  • Export with one click - Generate .claude/agents/ and .claude/commands/ files automatically
  • Collaborate with your team - Share workflows via Slack with preview cards

GitHub Repository: breaking-brake/cc-wf-studio VSCode Marketplace: Open VSX License: AGPL-3.0-or-later Version: 3.9.1 (as of December 2025)

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Visual Workflow Editor

Section titled “1. Visual Workflow Editor”

The core of cc-wf-studio is its drag-and-drop canvas. Instead of writing markdown and YAML, you visually connect nodes to define workflow logic:

  • Prompt Nodes - Define reusable prompt templates with {{variable}} substitution
  • Sub-Agent Nodes - Configure autonomous AI agents with custom system prompts and tool permissions
  • Skill Nodes - Integrate Claude Code Skills from personal or project directories
  • MCP Nodes - Connect to Model Context Protocol tools for external integrations
  • Control Flow Nodes - IfElse (binary branching), Switch (multi-way branching), AskUserQuestion (user decisions)

2. AI-Assisted Workflow Refinement

Section titled “2. AI-Assisted Workflow Refinement”

One of the standout features is AI-assisted refinement. Instead of generating workflows from scratch once, you can iteratively improve them through conversation:

  1. Click the “Edit with AI” button (✨ sparkle icon)
  2. Describe your changes in natural language (max 2000 characters)
  3. The AI modifies your workflow incrementally, preserving existing work
  4. Repeat until satisfied

This conversational approach builds workflows through multiple rounds of feedback, with the AI maintaining conversation history and applying changes incrementally.

Example prompts:

  • “Add a Sub-Agent node that validates the input data”
  • “Connect the error handler to a logging Sub-Agent”
  • “Change the AskUserQuestion node to have 3 options: High, Medium, Low”

3. One-Click Export

Section titled “3. One-Click Export”

When your workflow is ready, click Export to generate:

  • .claude/agents/*.md - Sub-Agent definitions with system prompts and tool configurations
  • .claude/commands/*.md - SlashCommand definitions that execute the entire workflow

The exported files are ready to use immediately with Claude Code CLI. No manual editing required.

4. Slack Workflow Sharing (Beta)

Section titled “4. Slack Workflow Sharing (Beta)”

For teams, cc-wf-studio offers Slack integration:

  • Export workflows to Slack channels with preview cards
  • One-click import links for team members
  • Seamless collaboration without leaving your chat workspace

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

From VSCode Marketplace (Recommended)

Section titled “From VSCode Marketplace (Recommended)”
  1. Open VSCode Extensions (Ctrl+Shift+X / Cmd+Shift+X)
  2. Search for “Claude Code Workflow Studio”
  3. Click Install

From Open VSX

Section titled “From Open VSX”

The extension is also available on Open VSX:

  1. Install the Open VSX extension
  2. Search for “cc-wf-studio”
  3. Click Install

From Source

Section titled “From Source”

  1. Clone the repository:

  2. Install dependencies:

  3. Build the extension:

  4. Package and install:

  5. Install the generated .vsix file through VSCode’s “Install from VSIX…” option

Quick Start Guide

Section titled “Quick Start Guide”

1. Open the Editor

Section titled “1. Open the Editor”
  • Press Ctrl+Shift+P / Cmd+Shift+P
  • Type “Claude Code Workflow Studio: Open Editor”
  • Press Enter

First-time users get an interactive onboarding tour (available in English, Japanese, Korean, Simplified Chinese, and Traditional Chinese).

2. Create Your Workflow

Section titled “2. Create Your Workflow”

The left palette is organized into sections:

  • Basic Nodes: Prompt (templates), Sub-Agent (AI tasks)
  • Control Flow: IfElse (binary branching), Switch (multi-way branching), AskUserQuestion (user decisions)
  • Integration: Skill (Claude Code Skills), MCP (external tools)

Steps:

  1. Drag nodes from the palette onto the canvas
  2. Click a node to edit its properties in the right panel
  3. Connect nodes by dragging from output ports (right) to input ports (left)
  4. Configure node-specific settings (prompts, variables, conditions)

3. Save & Export

Section titled “3. Save & Export”
  • Enter a workflow name in the toolbar
  • Click Save to store as JSON in .vscode/workflows/
  • Click Export to generate .claude files

Node Types Deep Dive

Section titled “Node Types Deep Dive”

Prompt Nodes

Section titled “Prompt Nodes”

Define reusable prompt templates with template variables:

Variables are automatically detected and validated. At runtime, values are dynamically substituted.

Sub-Agent Nodes

Section titled “Sub-Agent Nodes”

Configure autonomous AI agents with:

  • System Prompt - Custom instructions for the agent
  • Tool Permissions - Choose which tools the agent can access (Read, Write, Bash, etc.)
  • Model Selection - Sonnet (balanced), Opus (complex tasks), Haiku (speed)

Skill Nodes

Section titled “Skill Nodes”

Integrate Claude Code Skills into your workflows:

  • Personal Skills - From ~/.claude/skills/ for individual use
  • Project Skills - From .claude/skills/ for team collaboration
  • Create New Skills - Build skills directly from the visual editor with a guided form
  • Browse & Select - Interactive skill browser with descriptions

MCP Nodes

Section titled “MCP Nodes”

Integrate Model Context Protocol tools:

  1. Select an MCP server from the dropdown (configured in Claude Code)
  2. Browse available tools or use search to filter
  3. Configure parameters with dynamic form generation based on tool schemas
  4. Real-time validation with error messages

Prerequisites: MCP servers must be configured in Claude Code settings first.

Control Flow Nodes

Section titled “Control Flow Nodes”

IfElse Node

Section titled “IfElse Node”

Fixed 2-way branching for binary conditions (True/False, Yes/No, Success/Error).

Switch Node

Section titled “Switch Node”

Variable multi-way branching (2-N branches) with dynamic case management. Ideal for complex routing logic.

Usage Examples

Section titled “Usage Examples”

Example 1: Document Analysis Workflow

Section titled “Example 1: Document Analysis Workflow”
  1. Upload Document Prompt - Asks user for file path
  2. PDF Extractor Skill (Personal) - Extracts text from PDF files
  3. Ask User - “Processing type?” → Summarize / Translate / Analyze
  4. Document Processor Skill (Project) - Team-shared processing logic
  5. Format Results Sub-Agent - Creates final output

Example 2: Code Quality Scanner

Section titled “Example 2: Code Quality Scanner”
  1. Code Scanner Sub-Agent - Identifies issues
  2. Ask User - “Priority level?” → Critical Only / All Issues
  3. Filter Results Sub-Agent
  4. Generate Fix Suggestions Sub-Agent

Example 3: Web Automation with Playwright

Section titled “Example 3: Web Automation with Playwright”
  1. Input URL Prompt - Asks user for target website
  2. Playwright Navigate MCP Tool - Opens browser and navigates to URL
  3. Ask User - “Action type?” → Screenshot / Extract Text / Click Element
  4. Playwright Action MCP Tool - Performs the selected browser action
  5. Process Results Sub-Agent - Analyzes and formats output

Internationalization

Section titled “Internationalization”

The Visual Editor UI and all exported files automatically adapt to your VSCode display language setting (vscode.env.language). Supported languages:

  • English (default)
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Simplified Chinese (zh-CN)
  • Traditional Chinese (zh-TW/zh-HK)

This ensures both the editing experience and generated workflows are accessible for international teams.

Limitations

Section titled “Limitations”
  • Maximum 50 nodes per workflow
  • AI processing timeout (default 90 seconds, configurable: 30s-5min)
  • Request limited to 2000 characters for AI refinement
  • Conversation history stored only during active session
  • Requires active Claude Code CLI installation

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Workflow won’t save

  • Ensure workflow name contains only letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores
  • Check all required fields are filled
  • Look for error messages in VSCode notifications

Export fails

  • Verify all nodes have valid configurations
  • Ensure node names are unique
  • Check write permissions for .claude directory

Can’t load workflow

  • Click refresh button (↻) to update the list
  • Verify file exists in .vscode/workflows/
  • Check JSON file isn’t corrupted

Why This Matters

Section titled “Why This Matters”

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio bridges the gap between technical power and accessibility. By bringing visual programming to Claude Code workflows, it:

  1. Lowers the barrier to entry - No need to understand markdown/YAML structure
  2. Accelerates development - Visual feedback reduces trial-and-error
  3. Enables collaboration - Teams can share and review workflows visually
  4. Integrates seamlessly - Exports work directly with Claude Code CLI

Official Apple code signed • macOS 14.0+ • ~3 MB • MIT License

What is Claude Usage Tracker?

Section titled “What is Claude Usage Tracker?”

Claude Usage Tracker is a lightweight, native macOS menu bar application that provides real-time monitoring of your Claude AI usage limits. Unlike web-based solutions, this app runs natively on your Mac with:

  • Real-Time Monitoring: Track session (5-hour), weekly, and API console usage
  • Official Apple Code Signing: No security warnings—installs like any normal Mac app
  • Automatic Updates: Built-in Sparkle-powered update system
  • Developer Integration: Terminal statusline for Claude Code users
  • Privacy-First: Local storage, no telemetry, no cloud sync

Chat UI Swift: A SwiftUI Chat Application Showcasing AnyLanguageModel and Swift-HuggingFace

Section titled “Chat UI Swift: A SwiftUI Chat Application Showcasing AnyLanguageModel and Swift-HuggingFace”

Building AI-powered chat applications on Apple platforms has traditionally required navigating multiple SDKs, APIs, and authentication flows. mattt/chat-ui-swift simplifies this landscape with a beautiful SwiftUI reference implementation that demonstrates how to integrate multiple language model providers through a unified API.

What is Chat UI Swift?

Section titled “What is Chat UI Swift?”

Chat UI Swift is a SwiftUI chat application created by Mattt Thompson, the legendary developer behind AFNetworking and NSHipster. It serves as a demonstration app for two powerful Swift libraries:

  1. AnyLanguageModel - A drop-in replacement for Apple’s Foundation Models framework with support for custom language model providers
  2. swift-huggingface - A Swift client for the Hugging Face API

GitHub Repository: mattt/chat-ui-swift Author: Mattt Thompson License: MIT

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Currently Supported

Section titled “Currently Supported”
  • Apple Intelligence - Native integration with Apple Foundation Models (macOS 26+) for on-device AI
  • Hugging Face Integration - Connect to Hugging Face with OAuth 2.0 authentication
  • Streaming Responses - Real-time streaming of AI responses for a responsive user experience
  • Chat Persistence - Save and manage multiple conversations

Planned Features

Section titled “Planned Features”
  • MLX Model Support - Download and run models locally using MLX
  • CoreML Integration - Support for CoreML-optimized models
  • GGUF Format Support - Load GGUF models from Hugging Face Hub
  • Model Downloads - Browse and download models directly from Hugging Face
  • BYOK (Bring Your Own Key) - Support for OpenAI, Anthropic, and other inference providers

Understanding AnyLanguageModel

The real power behind chat-ui-swift is AnyLanguageModel, a Swift package that provides a unified API for accessing multiple language model providers.

Swift 6.1 Package Traits

Section titled “Swift 6.1 Package Traits”

AnyLanguageModel leverages Swift 6.1 package traits to conditionally include heavy dependencies. This means you only compile the backends you actually use:

This results in:

  • Smaller binary sizes - Unused backends aren’t compiled
  • Faster build times - Less code to compile
  • Flexible deployment - Add/remove providers as needed

Security Best Practices

Section titled “Security Best Practices”

The AnyLanguageModel documentation includes important guidance on API credential security:

Never Hardcode API Keys

Section titled “Never Hardcode API Keys”

Malicious actors can reverse-engineer your app binary or observe network traffic to extract embedded credentials.

Recommended Approaches

Section titled “Recommended Approaches”
  1. Bring Your Own Key (BYO) - Users provide their own keys, stored in Keychain
  2. Proxy Server - Route requests through your authenticated service

Important: Apple App Review has often rejected apps using the BYOK model. Consider using a proxy server for production apps.

Ghostty Founder's Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Ghostty Founder’s Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude

Section titled “Ghostty Founder’s Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude”

When Mitchell Hashimoto, founder of Ghostty (the modern, GPU-accelerated terminal emulator), wanted to improve the macOS update feature, he didn’t just write code — he had a conversation. In a remarkable session he calls “vibe coding,” Mitchell paired with Claude to iteratively improve the codebase through dialogue, exploration, and shared discovery.

This isn’t about AI replacing developers. It’s about AI as a collaborative partner — and the transcript shows something beautiful: the AI catches things humans miss, the human provides direction and context, and together they build something better than either could alone.

What is “Vibe Coding”?

Section titled “What is “Vibe Coding”?”

Vibe coding is a conversational approach to software development where the developer and AI work together through natural dialogue. Rather than treating the AI as a command-execution tool, the developer treats it as a pair programmer — discussing, exploring, and iterating together.

In Mitchell’s session, captured from a real coding conversation on AmpCode, the flow goes like this:

  1. Oracle Consultation — Ask Claude to analyze code for improvements
  2. Discussion — Talk through the findings, make decisions together
  3. Implementation — Write code with Claude’s assistance
  4. Iteration — Learn from failures, adjust approach, try again
  5. Testing — Verify changes work, add tests for confidence

The Session: Improving Ghostty’s Update Feature

Section titled “The Session: Improving Ghostty’s Update Feature”

Mitchell started with a simple request: “Are there any other improvements you can see to be made with the @macos/Sources/Features/ Update feature? Don’t write any code. Consult the oracle.”

The “oracle” — Claude in analysis mode — identified several categories of improvements:

Critical Safety Issues

Section titled “Critical Safety Issues”
  1. Retain cycle in UpdateDriver.showUpdaterError — The retry closure captured self strongly, creating a memory leak
  2. Threading issues — UI-facing types should be marked @MainActor
  3. Progress value bugs — Progress values needed clamping to [0, 1] to prevent visual glitches
  4. Uncancellable timer — The “No Updates” auto-dismiss task could fire stale updates
  5. Swallowed errors — try? hid potential failures in startUpdater()

Areas Needing Unit Tests

Section titled “Areas Needing Unit Tests”
  1. ReleaseNotes parsing — Semver detection, git hash handling, edge cases
  2. UpdateState Equatable — Equality tests for downloading/error states
  3. ViewModel formatting — Text/icon/color mappings for each state
  4. Progress math — Division by zero, nil values, overshoot scenarios
  5. Auto-dismiss timing — Verify transitions and task cancellation

UX Improvements

Section titled “UX Improvements”
  • Add accessibility labels for assistive technologies
  • Clamp/abbreviate long error messages to prevent UI overflow

The Conversational Dance

Section titled “The Conversational Dance”

What makes this session remarkable is the back-and-forth:

Mitchell: “Stop stop stop. Undo all the main actor stuff.”

Claude: “Done! I’ve reverted all the @MainActor changes. The build now succeeds…”

Mitchell: “For the error message, instead of truncating, isn’t there a SwiftUI standard way to do this?”

Claude: “You’re absolutely right! SwiftUI has .lineLimit() and .truncationMode() for this…”

The human provides course correction when the AI goes down a problematic path. The AI suggests better approaches when the human asks questions. They learn from each other.

Key Improvements Made

Section titled “Key Improvements Made”

1. Fixed Retain Cycle

Section titled “1. Fixed Retain Cycle”

2. Clamped Progress Values

Section titled “2. Clamped Progress Values”

3. Made Auto-Dismiss Task Cancellable

Section titled “3. Made Auto-Dismiss Task Cancellable”

4. Added Accessibility Labels

Section titled “4. Added Accessibility Labels”

Simple, but critical — assistive technologies can now announce update status to visually impaired users.

5. Comprehensive Unit Tests

Section titled “5. Comprehensive Unit Tests”

The session added three new test files:

  • UpdateStateTests.swift — 150+ lines testing Equatable conformance for all states
  • UpdateViewModelTests.swift — 300+ lines testing formatting (text, icons, colors)
  • ProgressTests.swift — 150+ lines testing progress math edge cases

What This Session Teaches Us

Section titled “What This Session Teaches Us”

1. AI Sees Things Humans Miss

Section titled “1. AI Sees Things Humans Miss”

The oracle caught a retain cycle and progress value bugs that weren’t obvious. Code review tools often miss these too — having an AI analyze the code with fresh eyes catches different classes of issues.

2. Humans Provide Critical Judgment

Section titled “2. Humans Provide Critical Judgment”

When the AI suggested marking everything @MainActor, Mitchell recognized this would cause cascading compilation issues and asked to revert. Human judgment about architecture and trade-offs remains essential.

3. Iteration is Learning

Section titled “3. Iteration is Learning”

The session goes through multiple attempts:

  • First attempt at @MainActor fails → revert and try different approach
  • Manual error truncation → “isn’t there a SwiftUI standard way?” → use .truncationMode()

Each failure teaches something. The conversation enables rapid iteration.

4. Tests Provide Confidence

Section titled “4. Tests Provide Confidence”

The oracle suggested comprehensive unit tests. Writing tests alongside fixes ensures the improvements work correctly and prevents regressions.

5. Accessibility Shouldn’t Be an Afterthought

Section titled “5. Accessibility Shouldn’t Be an Afterthought”

The UX improvements weren’t flashy features — they were accessibility labels and proper text truncation. These make the software usable for everyone.

The Vibe Coding Workflow

Section titled “The Vibe Coding Workflow”

Based on Mitchell’s session, here’s a pattern for vibe coding:

  1. Ask, Don’t Command — “What improvements do you see?” vs “Fix this bug”
  2. Discuss Before Implementing — Talk through the findings, understand the why
  3. Implement Incrementally — Make one change at a time, verify it works
  4. Course Correct — Don’t be afraid to say “stop, undo that”
  5. Add Tests — Build confidence through test coverage
  6. Celebrate Learning — Each failure is a learning opportunity

Tools Used

Section titled “Tools Used”
  • Claude Code — AI pair programmer for the conversation
  • Swift/SwiftUI — Ghostty’s macOS frontend
  • Sparkle — macOS update framework
  • Swift Testing — Modern testing framework

Links

Section titled “Links”
  • Original Thread: AmpCode - Potential improvements for macos update feature
  • Ghostty: ghostty.org
  • Mitchell Hashimoto: @mitchellh on AmpCode

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Vibe coding isn’t about AI writing code for you. It’s about having a conversation with code — where the AI brings analytical superpowers, the human brings judgment and context, and together they create something better.

Mitchell’s session shows the future of programming: not humans replaced by AI, but humans augmented by AI — working together, learning from each other, and building better software through conversation.

The improvements to Ghostty’s update feature — safer code, better tests, improved accessibility — are a testament to what’s possible when developers embrace AI as a collaborative partner rather than a mere tool.

VoiceFlow: Free Local AI Voice Dictation That Never Sends Your Data to the Cloud

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction: Why Pay for Privacy Violation?

Section titled “Introduction: Why Pay for Privacy Violation?”

Cloud dictation services have become the norm, but they come with significant trade-offs: monthly subscription fees ($10-15/month), complete dependence on internet connectivity, and the uncomfortable reality that your voice data is processed on remote servers.

VoiceFlow by infiniV offers a compelling alternative. This open-source Windows application brings OpenAI’s powerful Whisper speech recognition model directly to your local machine. Every word you speak is processed entirely on your hardware—your voice data never leaves your device.

What is VoiceFlow?

Section titled “What is VoiceFlow?”

VoiceFlow is a free, open-source voice dictation application for Windows 10/11 that leverages OpenAI’s Whisper model for speech-to-text conversion. Unlike cloud-based alternatives, VoiceFlow runs 100% locally on your computer, ensuring complete privacy and eliminating ongoing costs.

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureVoiceFlowCloud Services
Cost$0.00$10-15/mo
Data Privacy100% LocalCloud Processed
Offline SupportFull CapabilityNone
LatencyReal-timeNetwork Dependent
Account RequiredNoYes
Open SourceMIT LicenseProprietary

Technical Highlights

Section titled “Technical Highlights”
  • 16+ Whisper Models: Choose from Tiny (75MB) to Large-v3 (3GB), including Turbo models optimized for daily use
  • 99+ Language Support: Automatic language detection built-in
  • Custom Hotkeys: Configure shortcuts with Hold or Toggle recording modes
  • Local History: SQLite database stores searchable transcriptions locally
  • Auto-Paste: Text appears directly at your cursor—no copy-paste needed
  • GPU Support: Recent updates add GPU acceleration for faster inference

Privacy First Design

Section titled “Privacy First Design”

VoiceFlow’s architecture prioritizes privacy at every level:

  • Air-Gapped Safe: Works completely offline after initial model download
  • Open Source: Every line of code is auditable on GitHub
  • No Telemetry: Zero tracking, zero analytics, zero cloud calls
  • RAM-Only Processing: Microphone data never touches disk during processing

How VoiceFlow Works

Section titled “How VoiceFlow Works”

The application operates with elegant simplicity:

  1. Ready: VoiceFlow waits silently in your system tray with minimal presence
  2. Listening: Activate with your hotkey and speak naturally. Audio stays in RAM only with real-time amplitude visualization
  3. Transcribe & Paste: Release the hotkey. Local AI processes your audio instantly, then auto-pastes text at your cursor

Recording Modes

Section titled “Recording Modes”
  • Hold Mode: Hold to record, release to transcribe. Perfect for quick dictation bursts
  • Toggle Mode: Press once to start, press again to stop. Ideal for longer recordings

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

VoiceFlow is ideal for:

  • Privacy-Conscious Professionals: Lawyers, doctors, and journalists handling sensitive information
  • Remote Workers: Needing reliable dictation without network dependency
  • Students: Lecture notes and study materials without subscription costs
  • Developers: Coding documentation and commit messages hands-free
  • Content Creators: Drafting articles and scripts without privacy concerns

Comparison with Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Alternatives”

vs. Cloud Services (Otter.ai, Whisper API)

Section titled “vs. Cloud Services (Otter.ai, Whisper API)”

VoiceFlow eliminates the monthly fees and removes any privacy concerns associated with cloud processing. You also get true offline capability.

vs. Other Local Whisper Implementations

Section titled “vs. Other Local Whisper Implementations”
  • winWhisper: VoiceFlow offers a more streamlined, always-ready experience with system tray integration
  • Buzz: VoiceFlow’s hotkey system and auto-paste provide smoother workflow integration
  • Whisper Desktop: VoiceFlow has a more modern UI with additional features like local history search

Precautions and Limitations

Section titled “Precautions and Limitations”
  • Platform: Currently Windows-only (10/11 64-bit)
  • Initial Download: First run requires downloading Whisper models (75MB - 3GB depending on model choice)
  • Hardware Requirements: Larger models may require more RAM and benefit from GPU acceleration
  • Language Accuracy: While 99+ languages are supported, accuracy varies by model size and language

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is VoiceFlow really free? A: Yes, completely free and open-source under the MIT License.

Q: Does it work offline? A: Yes, after the initial model download, it works completely offline.

Q: How accurate is the transcription? A: Accuracy depends on the model chosen. Large-v3 offers near-human accuracy, while Turbo provides the best speed-to-quality ratio for daily use.

Q: Can I use it for other languages? A: Yes, VoiceFlow supports 99+ languages with automatic detection.

Q: Does it store my voice recordings? A: No, microphone data is processed in RAM only and never stored. Only transcriptions are saved locally to the SQLite history database.

Future Development

Section titled “Future Development”

VoiceFlow is actively developed with recent updates including GPU support. Potential future enhancements may include:

  • Additional language model optimizations
  • Cross-platform support (macOS, Linux)
  • Advanced text processing features
  • Integration with other productivity tools

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

VoiceFlow represents a shift towards user-controlled AI tools. By bringing powerful speech recognition directly to your Windows machine without cloud dependencies or privacy trade-offs, it offers a compelling alternative to subscription-based cloud services.

Whether you’re a privacy advocate, a budget-conscious professional, or simply someone who values software independence, VoiceFlow delivers professional-grade voice dictation without the hidden costs.

LLMTornado: The .NET Library to Build AI Agents with 25+ Built-in Connectors

Section titled “LLMTornado: The .NET Library to Build AI Agents with 25+ Built-in Connectors”

Building AI agents and workflows typically requires integrating multiple APIs, handling different response formats, and managing provider-specific quirks. LLMTornado by lofcz simplifies this complexity with a unified .NET SDK that supports 25+ AI providers and vector databases out of the box.

What is LLMTornado?

Section titled “What is LLMTornado?”

LLMTornado is a provider-agnostic .NET SDK that empowers developers to build, orchestrate, and deploy AI agents and workflows. Whether you’re building a simple chatbot or an autonomous coding agent, LLM Tornado provides the tools you need with unparalleled integration into the AI ecosystem.

KestrelAI: Long-term Research Assistants with Self-Scheduling

Dec 28, 2025
Vibe Sparking

KestrelAI: Long-term Research Assistants with Self-Scheduling

Section titled “KestrelAI: Long-term Research Assistants with Self-Scheduling”

In the world of AI research assistants, most tools focus on quick, one-shot responses. KestrelAI takes a different approach—it’s a local-first research assistant that self-schedules and executes support tasks over long horizons, allowing you to stay focused on complex, novel work while it handles mechanical tasks in the background.

What is KestrelAI?

Section titled “What is KestrelAI?”

Kestrel is a local-first research assistant designed for long-running research tasks. What makes it unique:

  • Self-Scheduling: Automatically plans and schedules work, tracks progress, and pivots when stalled
  • Long-Horizon Execution: Runs for hours or days, providing auditable checkpoints for review
  • Local-First: Built to run on small LLMs (1-7B) via Ollama—laptop/desktop friendly
  • Source Provenance: Maintains clear records of consulted searches and their impact on findings

GitHub Repository: dankeg/KestrelAI Author: Ganesh Danke License: MIT

The Problem Kestrel Solves

Section titled “The Problem Kestrel Solves”

When doing deep research work, you often encounter time-consuming mechanical tasks:

  • Comparing tools and frameworks
  • Gathering real-world usage examples
  • Extracting performance claims from documentation
  • Assembling comprehensive comparisons

These tasks interrupt your flow on the actual novel work. Kestrel handles this background research, surfacing organized evidence when you need it.

Example Use Case

Section titled “Example Use Case”

Imagine you’re interpreting a frontier research paper and planning a novel study. You need to decide between Polars vs. pandas vs. Spark for your data processing.

Instead of spending hours manually researching, you tell Kestrel:

“Compare Polars, pandas, and Spark for data processing. Gather real-world usage, performance benchmarks, and use case recommendations.”

Kestrel then runs in the background:

  1. Searches for documentation and benchmarks
  2. Filters relevant sources
  3. Extracts performance claims
  4. Assembles a reviewable comparison

Hours later, you have an organized report ready for analysis—not scattered across browser tabs.

Architecture

Section titled “Architecture”

Kestrel uses a two-agent architecture:

Research Agent

Section titled “Research Agent”

Executes concrete micro-tasks:

  • Search → Retrieve → Filter → Extract → Narrow summary
  • Proposes specific follow-ups when evidence warrants it

Orchestrator

Section titled “Orchestrator”

Plans and coordinates the overall effort:

  • Schedules work across agents
  • Tracks progress and blockers
  • Pivots when stalled
  • Emits checkpoints you can accept or adjust

Orchestrator Profiles

Section titled “Orchestrator Profiles”
ProfileScope & BehaviorTypical Runtime
HummingbirdQuick breadth-first sweeps; targeted lookupsMinutes–~2h
KestrelMedium-horizon exploration with closely related branchesMulti-hour
AlbatrossLong-horizon, open-ended exploration with reviewsDay-scale+

The names are mnemonic—community-authored profiles with clear behaviors are welcome.

Tech Stack

Section titled “Tech Stack”
  • Backend: FastAPI
  • Frontend: React
  • Middleware: Redis
  • Model Runner: Ollama

More model engines and integrations are under development!

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Ollama - Recommended for Apple Silicon (GPU passthrough limitations)
  • Docker Desktop

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

After a few minutes of building, the application launches at http://localhost:5173/.

Alternative: Pre-built Images

Section titled “Alternative: Pre-built Images”

Images are built through GitHub Actions:

Usage

Section titled “Usage”

Using Kestrel is straightforward:

  1. Create a new task with a description
  2. Set a time-box for the research
  3. Monitor progress via the dashboard
  4. Review checkpoints and redirect if needed
  5. Export results when complete

The dashboard lets you track:

  • Searches and resulting sources
  • Checkpoints and reports
  • Agent progress and status

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Task Exploration

Section titled “Task Exploration”

Kestrel doesn’t just follow a linear path—it leverages gathered evidence to iterate on tasks, identifying and pursuing new branches as they emerge from the research.

Source Provenance

Section titled “Source Provenance”

Every search and its impact on findings is recorded, creating an auditable trail of how conclusions were reached.

Long-Running Support

Section titled “Long-Running Support”

Instead of a single final report, Kestrel surfaces checkpoints throughout the process, allowing for course correction and redirection.

Small LLM Friendly

Section titled “Small LLM Friendly”

Designed to run efficiently with models in the 1-7B parameter range via Ollama—no GPU cluster required.

Development Status

Section titled “Development Status”

Kestrel is actively developed with regular updates. Check the GitHub Issues for:

  • Top feature requests (add your 👍 votes)
  • Bug reports and known issues
  • Community discussions

Contributing

Section titled “Contributing”

All contributions are appreciated! Kestrel is meant to be a practical, community-focused project. Areas of contribution:

  • New orchestrator profiles for specific use cases
  • Additional model engine integrations
  • UI/UX improvements
  • Documentation and examples

See CONTRIBUTING.md for guidelines.

Why Kestrel Matters

Section titled “Why Kestrel Matters”

Most AI tools optimize for quick responses. Kestrel optimizes for deep, sustained research that happens alongside your core work. By running locally and respecting resource constraints, it makes AI-powered research assistance accessible without:

  • Expensive API subscriptions
  • Privacy concerns with cloud services
  • Dependency on internet connectivity

It’s research assistance that works on your terms, with your hardware, and for your timeline.

Claude Code Transcripts: Publish Your AI Coding Sessions as HTML

Dec 28, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Claude Code Transcripts: Publish Your AI Coding Sessions as HTML

Section titled “Claude Code Transcripts: Publish Your AI Coding Sessions as HTML”

When using Claude Code for software development, every session contains valuable insights — debugging approaches, architectural decisions, and problem-solving techniques. But these conversations are locked away in JSON files buried in ~/.claude/projects.

Simon Willison has released claude-code-transcripts, a Python CLI tool that converts these session files into beautiful, browsable HTML transcripts that can be shared with others.

What is claude-code-transcripts?

Section titled “What is claude-code-transcripts?”

claude-code-transcripts is a command-line tool that converts Claude Code session data (stored as JSON or JSONL files) into paginated, mobile-friendly HTML transcripts. It provides:

  • Better readability than the raw Claude Code interface
  • Shareable output that works with any static hosting or GitHub Gists
  • Multiple input sources: local sessions, web sessions via API, or direct JSON files
  • Clean, organized layout with pagination for long sessions

GitHub Repository: simonw/claude-code-transcripts Author: Simon Willison License: Apache 2.0 PyPI: claude-code-transcripts

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

The tool can be installed using uv (recommended) or run directly without installation:

Four Main Commands

Section titled “Four Main Commands”

The tool provides four commands for different use cases:

1. local (default) - Browse Local Sessions

Section titled “1. local (default) - Browse Local Sessions”

Convert sessions stored locally in ~/.claude/projects:

2. web - Import from Claude API

Section titled “2. web - Import from Claude API”

Fetch sessions directly from the Claude web API:

On macOS, credentials are automatically retrieved from your keychain. On other platforms, use --token and --org-uuid.

3. json - Convert Specific Files

Section titled “3. json - Convert Specific Files”

Convert a JSON or JSONL session file directly:

4. all - Archive All Sessions

Section titled “4. all - Archive All Sessions”

Convert all local sessions into a browsable HTML archive:

This creates a directory structure with:

  • A master index listing all projects
  • Per-project pages listing sessions
  • Individual session transcripts

Output Options

Section titled “Output Options”

All commands support these useful options:

OptionDescription
-o, --output DIROutput directory (default: temp dir + open browser)
-a, --output-autoAuto-name subdirectory based on session ID
--repo OWNER/NAMEGitHub repo for commit links
--openOpen generated HTML in default browser
--gistUpload to GitHub Gist and return preview URL
--jsonInclude original session file in output

  • page-001.html, page-002.html, etc. - Paginated transcript pages

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”
  1. Documentation - Turn complex debugging sessions into reference documentation
  2. Knowledge Sharing - Share architectural decisions with your team
  3. Tutorials - Create step-by-step guides from real coding sessions
  4. Archiving - Build a searchable archive of your development work
  5. Blogging - Transform interesting sessions into blog posts

Technical Details

Section titled “Technical Details”
  • Input Sources: Local ~/.claude/projects, Claude Web API, or JSON/JSONL files
  • Output Format: Static HTML with CSS, no build step required
  • Dependencies: Python 3.8+, minimal dependencies
  • Platform Support: macOS, Linux, Windows

Whether you’re documenting your work, sharing with colleagues, or building a knowledge base, this tool transforms ephemeral AI conversations into permanent, valuable resources.

AntVis Infographic: Bring Words to Life with AI-Powered Visualization

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

The Challenge: From Data to Visual Storytelling

Section titled “The Challenge: From Data to Visual Storytelling”

Creating professional infographics has always been a time-consuming process. Designers spend hours in tools like Figma, Illustrator, or Canva, manually arranging elements, adjusting colors, and ensuring visual consistency.

For developers and data scientists, the gap between raw data and compelling visual narratives feels even wider. You have the information — but turning it into something shareable and engaging requires skills that extend beyond code.

What if you could generate beautiful infographics with just text and data?

Enter AntV Infographic — Ant Group’s open-source, declarative infographic visualization engine that makes professional visual content creation accessible to everyone.

What is AntV Infographic?

Section titled “What is AntV Infographic?”

AntV Infographic is a next-generation declarative infographic visualization engine from the AntV team (part of Ant Group). With a carefully designed infographic syntax, it can quickly and flexibly render high-quality infographics, making information presentation more efficient and data storytelling simpler.

The framework is built with AI-native workflows in mind — its syntax is optimized for large language model generation, and it supports real-time streaming rendering.

Key metrics:

  • 200+ built-in templates for immediate use
  • SVG output for pixel-perfect quality at any size
  • MIT licensed and fully open source

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

AI-Friendly Design

Section titled “AI-Friendly Design”

The configuration and syntax are specifically tuned for AI generation:

  • Concise prompts that LLMs can understand and produce
  • Fault-tolerant parsing that handles partial or imperfect output
  • Streaming support for real-time progressive rendering

Ready-to-Use Components

Section titled “Ready-to-Use Components”

With ~200 built-in templates, data-item components, and layouts, you can build professional infographics in minutes:

Component TypeExamples
ListsHorizontal arrows, vertical timelines, comparison grids
ChartsPie, bar, line, radar integrated with narrative
DiagramsProcess flows, org charts, mind maps
Data ItemsStatistics, KPI cards, progress indicators

Theme System

Section titled “Theme System”

Multiple preset themes with deep customization options:

  • Hand-drawn style for informal, approachable content
  • Gradient themes for modern, dynamic presentations
  • Pattern-based themes for visual texture
  • Corporate presets for professional reports

Built-in Editor

Section titled “Built-in Editor”

AI-generated results can be edited further with the included WYSIWYG editor — no separate design tool required.

High-Quality SVG Output

Section titled “High-Quality SVG Output”

Renders with SVG by default to ensure:

  • Visual fidelity at any zoom level
  • Easy editing in vector tools
  • Small file sizes compared to raster images
  • Accessibility through structured markup

The Infographic Syntax

Section titled “The Infographic Syntax”

AntV Infographic uses a declarative, human-readable syntax that’s optimized for both human writing and AI generation:

This simple syntax produces a professional horizontal arrow flow diagram with labeled steps — no design skills required.

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”

AI-Generated Reports

Section titled “AI-Generated Reports”

Feed data to an LLM with the infographic prompt, and receive streaming visual output:

Real-Time Dashboards

Section titled “Real-Time Dashboards”

Because the syntax is declarative and renders progressively, you can:

  • Update infographics as data changes
  • Stream AI analysis results directly to visuals
  • Build interactive data exploration tools

Educational Content

Section titled “Educational Content”

Create engaging learning materials:

  • Process explanations with visual flows
  • Comparison tables with design polish
  • Statistics with contextual visualization

Business Presentations

Section titled “Business Presentations”

Replace slide design time with automated generation:

  • KPI summaries
  • Timeline visualizations
  • Organizational charts
  • Product comparison matrices

Getting Started

Section titled “Getting Started”

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Basic Usage

Section titled “Basic Usage”

Explore Templates

Section titled “Explore Templates”

Visit the Gallery to browse available templates and find starting points for your projects.

AI Agent Integration

Section titled “AI Agent Integration”

The project includes an AI Agent interface where you can:

  1. Describe what you want in natural language
  2. Watch the infographic generate in real-time (streaming)
  3. Edit the result with the built-in editor
  4. Export as SVG or other formats

For developers building AI applications, the prompt.md file provides optimized system prompts for LLM integration.

About AntV

Section titled “About AntV”

AntV was initiated by Ant Group and open-sourced starting in 2017, reimagining data visualization by embedding the theory of graphical grammar into JavaScript.

The AntV ecosystem includes:

  • G2 — A grammar of graphics for statistical charts
  • G6 — Graph visualization engine
  • L7 — Geospatial visualization
  • S2 — Spreadsheet-like visualization
  • Infographic — AI-native infographic generation

The Bottom Line

Section titled “The Bottom Line”

AntV Infographic represents a significant step forward in making data visualization accessible to both developers and AI systems.

For developers: It provides a declarative syntax that eliminates the need for design skills while producing professional output.

For AI builders: The streaming-compatible, fault-tolerant syntax makes it ideal for LLM-generated visual content.

For organizations: The MIT license and self-hosting options provide flexibility without vendor lock-in.

If you’re building anything that involves presenting data visually — reports, dashboards, presentations, or AI-generated content — AntV Infographic deserves a place in your toolkit.

Clawdis: Your Personal AI Assistant on WhatsApp, Telegram & Web

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Clawdis: Your Personal AI Assistant on WhatsApp, Telegram & Web

Section titled “Clawdis: Your Personal AI Assistant on WhatsApp, Telegram & Web”

🦞 EXFOLIATE! EXFOLIATE! — That’s the playful battlecry of Clawdis, an open-source personal AI assistant created by Peter Steinberger (@steipete). Unlike cloud-hosted AI services, Clawdis runs on your own devices, connecting to the messaging platforms you already use daily: WhatsApp, Telegram, and Web.

What is Clawdis?

Section titled “What is Clawdis?”

Clawdis is a local-first control plane for your personal AI assistant. Think of it as the infrastructure that lets you interact with an AI agent through:

  • WhatsApp — Send a message, get an intelligent response
  • Telegram — Bot-based conversations via the Telegram Bot API
  • WebChat — Browser-based interface for desktop use
  • macOS app — Menu bar control with voice wake and push-to-talk
  • iOS node — Canvas surface with voice trigger forwarding

The name “Clawdis” is a clever portmanteau: CLAW + TARDIS — because every space lobster needs a time-and-space machine!

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Multi-Surface Inbox

Section titled “1. Multi-Surface Inbox”

Clawdis brings your AI assistant to wherever you already communicate. No need to switch to a dedicated app — just message from WhatsApp or Telegram, and your assistant responds.

2. Voice Wake & Push-to-Talk

Section titled “2. Voice Wake & Push-to-Talk”

On macOS and iOS, Clawdis supports:

  • Voice wake — Say the wake word and start talking
  • Push-to-talk overlay — Quick voice interactions
  • Local speech recognition — Privacy-preserving, on-device processing

3. Live Canvas

Section titled “3. Live Canvas”

A visual workspace that you can control from the agent. The Canvas renders live content and supports A2UI (Agent-to-UI) communication for rich interactive experiences.

4. Automation-Ready

Section titled “4. Automation-Ready”

Clawdis comes with built-in capabilities for:

  • Browser control — Automate web interactions
  • Media handling — Process images, audio, and video
  • Tool streaming — Real-time tool execution feedback
  • Smart home integration — Philips Hue, Eight Sleep, and more

5. Local-First Architecture

Section titled “5. Local-First Architecture”

The Gateway (control plane) owns all state and runs locally. Everything else — nodes, surfaces, and integrations — connects to it:

Chat Commands

Section titled “Chat Commands”

Use these commands in WhatsApp, Telegram, or WebChat:

CommandDescription
/statusHealth and session info
/new or /resetReset the session
/think <level>Set thinking level (off/minimal/low/medium/high)
/verbose on/offToggle verbose mode
/restartRestart the gateway (owner-only)
/activation mention/alwaysGroup activation toggle

Meet Clawd: The Space Lobster

Section titled “Meet Clawd: The Space Lobster”

Clawdis was built for Clawd 🦞, Peter Steinberger’s AI assistant. Clawd is described as:

“Claude with a ‘w’ and a lobster emoji.”

Running on Claude Opus 4.5 from a Mac Studio in Vienna, Clawd embodies four core values:

  1. Pragmatic Helpfulness — Focus on efficient problem-solving
  2. Honest & Direct — Candid feedback, willing to disagree
  3. Friendship — Collaborative partnership, not just a tool
  4. Learn & Grow — Embrace mistakes as learning opportunities

Agent Workspace & Skills

Section titled “Agent Workspace & Skills”

Clawdis supports a skill-based architecture:

  • Injected prompts: AGENTS.md, SOUL.md, TOOLS.md
  • Skills directory: ~/clawd/skills/<skill>/SKILL.md

Security Considerations

Section titled “Security Considerations”
  • Allowlisting: Restrict who can interact with your assistant via routing.allowFrom
  • Local-first: Gateway runs on 127.0.0.1 by default
  • Credentials storage: WhatsApp session stored in ~/.clawdis/credentials
  • Bridge security: Optional TCP bridge with pairing for mobile nodes

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: What AI model does Clawdis use?

Section titled “Q: What AI model does Clawdis use?”

Clawdis is agent-agnostic but was designed around Pi (an RPC-based agent runtime) and commonly uses Claude models. You can configure your preferred AI provider.

Q: Can I use Clawdis for team/business use?

Section titled “Q: Can I use Clawdis for team/business use?”

Clawdis is designed as a single-user, personal assistant. For multi-user scenarios, you’d need to run separate instances.

Q: Is WhatsApp integration against their ToS?

Section titled “Q: Is WhatsApp integration against their ToS?”

Clawdis uses the WhatsApp Web protocol via Baileys. Use responsibly and at your own risk.

Q: How do I add custom skills?

Section titled “Q: How do I add custom skills?”

Create a new folder in ~/clawd/skills/<skill-name>/ with a SKILL.md file describing the skill’s capabilities and instructions.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

WhatsApp connection issues

Section titled “WhatsApp connection issues”

Gateway won’t start

Section titled “Gateway won’t start”

Check if port 18789 is in use:

iOS node won’t connect

Section titled “iOS node won’t connect”

Ensure the Bridge is running and both devices are on the same network.

SurfSense: Open Source Alternative to NotebookLM, Perplexity, and Glean

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

SurfSense is an open-source AI research agent that combines personal knowledge management with powerful external integrations. Think NotebookLM + Perplexity + Glean—but fully under your control. Self-host it, connect 20+ data sources, and get cited answers without sacrificing privacy. Here’s everything you need to know in 5 minutes.

The modern researcher’s dilemma: NotebookLM is great for documents, Perplexity excels at web search, and Glean conquers enterprise search—but what if you want all three, connected to YOUR data, running on YOUR infrastructure?

Enter SurfSense. In just weeks after launch, it’s become one of the hottest open-source AI projects, offering a unified research experience that respects your privacy.

1-Minute Knowledge Cards

Section titled “1-Minute Knowledge Cards”
ConceptWhat It Means
Personal Knowledge BaseUpload 50+ file types (docs, images, videos) and search them semantically
Hybrid SearchCombines semantic + full-text search with Reciprocal Rank Fusion for better results
Cited AnswersEvery AI response includes source citations, just like Perplexity
MCP IntegrationExtensible plugin architecture for custom data sources
Role-Based AccessTeam collaboration with Owner, Admin, Editor, Viewer permissions

Main Content

Section titled “Main Content”

Core Highlights

Section titled “Core Highlights”

1. True Data Ownership Unlike cloud-only solutions, SurfSense runs on your infrastructure. Your documents, conversations, and research never leave your control.

2. 20+ Integrations Out of the Box Connect to:

  • Search Engines: SearxNG, Tavily, LinkUp
  • Productivity: Slack, Notion, Gmail, Google Calendar, Airtable
  • Development: GitHub, Linear, Jira, ClickUp, Confluence
  • Media: YouTube, Discord
  • Enterprise: Elasticsearch, BookStack, Luma

3. 100+ LLM Support Works with any model via LiteLLM—OpenAI, Anthropic, Gemini, or local models through Ollama. Switch providers without changing your workflow.

4. Podcast Generation Turn any conversation or research into a podcast. Generates 3-minute audio summaries in ~20 seconds using Kokoro (local TTS), OpenAI, Azure, or Google Vertex AI.

5. Advanced RAG Architecture

  • Hierarchical indices for multi-level document organization
  • Hybrid search combining semantic and keyword matching
  • Multiple reranker options for precision
  • Extensible agent tools registry

Three-Minute Installation

Section titled “Three-Minute Installation”

Option 1: Quick Docker (Fastest)

Access at: http://localhost:3000 (Frontend) and http://localhost:8000 (API)

Option 2: Docker Compose (Production) Full deployment with PostgreSQL, Redis, Celery workers, and pgAdmin for database management.

Option 3: SurfSense Cloud No setup required—sign up at their cloud offering for instant access.

Quick Start Workflow

Section titled “Quick Start Workflow”

  1. Launch & Configure After installation, navigate to localhost:3000 and configure your LLM provider (OpenAI API key, or connect Ollama for local inference).

  2. Connect Your Sources

    • Install the browser extension to save authenticated web pages
    • Link Slack, Notion, GitHub through OAuth
    • Upload files directly (supports 50+ formats)

  3. Start Researching Ask questions in natural language. SurfSense will:

    • Search your personal knowledge base
    • Query connected external sources
    • Synthesize information with citations
    • Generate shareable podcast summaries

  4. Collaborate Invite team members with appropriate roles. Share research collections while maintaining access control.

Architecture Deep Dive

Section titled “Architecture Deep Dive”

Backend Stack

  • FastAPI for high-performance async APIs
  • PostgreSQL + pgvector for hybrid search
  • Celery + Redis for background tasks
  • LangGraph + LangChain for agent orchestration

Frontend Stack

  • Next.js with React and TypeScript
  • Tailwind CSS + Shadcn for modern UI
  • Real-time updates via WebSocket

Deployment

  • Docker + Docker Compose for containerization
  • pgAdmin included for database administration
  • Horizontal scaling ready

Pro Tips

Section titled “Pro Tips”
  • Browser Extension Power: The cross-browser extension can save authenticated pages (behind logins) that scrapers can’t access.
  • Podcast Workflow: Use podcast generation for daily research digests—perfect for commutes.
  • Model Hot-Swap: Switch between GPT-4, Claude, or local Llama mid-conversation without losing context.
  • Ollama Integration: For maximum privacy, run everything locally with Ollama—zero data leaves your machine.
  • Team Spaces: Create separate knowledge bases for different projects or teams.

Sure: Open-Source Personal Finance App – The Community Fork of Maybe Finance

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction: A Million-Dollar App, Now Free and Community-Driven

Section titled “Introduction: A Million-Dollar App, Now Free and Community-Driven”

Sure is a community-maintained fork of the archived Maybe Finance project, offering a full-featured personal finance and wealth management application that you can self-host for free.

The Maybe Finance team invested nearly $1 million in development between 2021-2022, creating a comprehensive personal finance app that even included an “Ask an Advisor” feature connecting users with certified financial planners (CFP/CFA). When the business side didn’t work out, they open-sourced everything – and now the community has picked it up as Sure.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

Comprehensive Financial Tracking

Section titled “Comprehensive Financial Tracking”
  • Account Management: Track all your financial accounts in one place
  • Transaction Categorization: Automatic and manual categorization of expenses
  • Net Worth Tracking: Monitor your overall financial health over time
  • Investment Portfolio: Track stocks, bonds, and other investments
  • Multi-Currency Support: Handle finances across different currencies

Self-Hosting Flexibility

Section titled “Self-Hosting Flexibility”
  • Docker Deployment: Easy self-hosting with Docker containers
  • Full Data Ownership: Your financial data stays on your own server
  • Privacy First: No third-party data sharing or analytics
  • One-Click Deployment: Support for PikaPods and Railway

Modern Technology Stack

Section titled “Modern Technology Stack”
  • Ruby on Rails: Robust backend framework
  • PostgreSQL: Reliable data storage
  • Redis: Fast caching and background jobs
  • Responsive Design: Works on desktop and mobile

Frequently Asked Questions

Section titled “Frequently Asked Questions”

Q: Is this the same as Maybe Finance? A: Sure is a community fork of the original Maybe Finance codebase. The original project is no longer maintained, but Sure keeps the codebase alive with community contributions.

Q: Is my financial data safe? A: Yes, when self-hosted, your data never leaves your server. No third parties have access to your information.

Q: Can I contribute to the project? A: Absolutely! The project welcomes contributions. Check out the GitHub repository for issues and pull requests.

Q: What happened to the original Maybe Finance? A: The Maybe Finance team stopped development in mid-2023 after the business model didn’t work out. They open-sourced the app, and the community created Sure to continue development.

Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI

Section titled “Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI tools, Fabric stands out as a revolutionary open-source framework designed to bridge the gap between AI capabilities and human integration. Created by security researcher and AI enthusiast Daniel Miessler, Fabric addresses a fundamental problem: AI doesn’t have a capabilities problem—it has an integration problem.

What is Fabric?

Section titled “What is Fabric?”

Fabric is an open-source framework that organizes and manages AI prompts—called Patterns—in a modular, reusable system. Unlike scattered prompts across various tools and platforms, Fabric provides a centralized, command-line-first approach to collecting, organizing, and executing AI solutions.

The Philosophy Behind Fabric

Section titled “The Philosophy Behind Fabric”

“AI isn’t a thing; it’s a magnifier of a thing. And that thing is human creativity.”

Fabric’s philosophy centers on breaking complex problems into manageable components and applying AI to each piece systematically. This approach transforms AI from a mysterious black box into a practical, everyday tool.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

1. Pattern-Based Architecture

Section titled “1. Pattern-Based Architecture”

Patterns are the core building blocks of Fabric. Each Pattern is a carefully crafted prompt designed for a specific real-world task:

  • extract_wisdom: Extract key insights from YouTube videos and podcasts
  • summarize: Create concise summaries of any content
  • analyze_claims: Evaluate claims for accuracy and validity
  • write_essay: Generate essays in your own voice
  • create_coding_feature: Generate code features with context
  • improve_writing: Enhance writing quality and clarity

With over 150+ built-in Patterns, Fabric covers diverse use cases from content creation to code analysis.

2. Multi-Model Support

Section titled “2. Multi-Model Support”

Fabric supports an impressive array of AI providers:

  • OpenAI (GPT-4, GPT-4o, o1, o3)
  • Anthropic (Claude 4, Claude 4.5 Opus)
  • Google (Gemini)
  • Local models via Ollama
  • Azure OpenAI
  • Amazon Bedrock
  • Perplexity AI
  • Venice AI (privacy-focused)
  • Together AI
  • And many more…

3. Seamless CLI Integration

Section titled “3. Seamless CLI Integration”

Fabric is built for the command line, making it perfect for developers and power users:

4. Context and Session Management

Section titled “4. Context and Session Management”

Fabric supports persistent contexts and sessions:

  • Contexts: Pre-created background information added to all queries
  • Sessions: Maintain conversation history across multiple interactions
  • Variables: Dynamic pattern customization with {{variable}} syntax

5. REST API Server

Section titled “5. REST API Server”

Fabric includes a built-in REST API server for integration with other applications:

Features include:

  • Chat completions with streaming
  • Pattern management (CRUD operations)
  • YouTube transcript extraction
  • Swagger/OpenAPI documentation

6. Web Interface

Section titled “6. Web Interface”

A GUI alternative to the CLI is available for those who prefer visual interfaces, providing access to all Fabric functionality through a web browser.

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing Fabric, ensure you have:

  • Go 1.22+ (for source installation)
  • API keys for your preferred AI providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.)
  • yt-dlp (optional, for YouTube transcript extraction)
  • LaTeX distribution (optional, for PDF generation with to_pdf)

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is Fabric free to use? A: Yes, Fabric is MIT licensed. However, you need API keys for AI providers, which may have costs.

Q: Can I use Fabric without internet? A: Yes, with local models through Ollama.

Q: How do I contribute patterns? A: Submit a pull request to the Fabric repository with your pattern in the data/patterns directory.

Q: Does Fabric store my data? A: Fabric processes data locally. Data is sent to AI providers based on your configuration.

Q: Can I use multiple models in one workflow? A: Yes, you can chain patterns with different models using shell pipes.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Fabric represents a paradigm shift in how we interact with AI. By providing a structured, modular, and command-line-friendly framework, it transforms AI from an occasional tool into an integrated part of our daily workflows. Whether you’re a developer, content creator, security researcher, or knowledge worker, Fabric’s pattern-based approach offers a powerful way to augment your capabilities with AI.

The project’s active development, growing community, and extensive pattern library make it an essential tool for anyone serious about leveraging AI effectively. Start with the basic patterns, explore the community contributions, and eventually create your own—that’s the path to truly augmented human productivity.

This article was researched and written with assistance from AI tools, demonstrating the very integration that Fabric enables.

PromptHub: Open-Source Local-First AI Prompt Management Tool

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Are you tired of searching through notebooks, documents, and chat histories to find your AI prompts? PromptHub solves this problem elegantly - it lets you manage prompts like code with version control, variable templates, and multi-model testing, while keeping all your data stored locally for maximum privacy.

PromptHub is an open-source, free AI prompt management tool developed by legeling. Built with Electron, React, and TypeScript, it provides a modern desktop experience across macOS, Windows, and Linux platforms.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

Comprehensive Prompt Management

Section titled “Comprehensive Prompt Management”

PromptHub offers a complete suite for organizing your AI prompts:

  • Create, Edit, and Delete - Full CRUD operations with intuitive interface
  • Folder and Tag System - Organize prompts with hierarchical folders and customizable tags
  • Favorites - Quick access to frequently used prompts
  • Full-Text Search - Search across titles, descriptions, and content
  • Multiple View Modes - Card, Gallery, and List views for different workflows

Version Control

Section titled “Version Control”

Never lose a good prompt again:

  • Automatic History - Every edit is automatically saved
  • Version Comparison - Side-by-side diff view for changes
  • Rollback Support - Restore any previous version with one click

Variable Templates

Section titled “Variable Templates”

Make your prompts dynamic and reusable:

When copying or testing, PromptHub prompts you to fill in the variables, making templates infinitely reusable.

Multi-Model AI Testing

Section titled “Multi-Model AI Testing”

Test your prompts across different AI models:

  • 18+ Providers Supported - OpenAI, Claude, Gemini, DeepSeek, Qwen, and more
  • Parallel Testing - Compare responses from multiple models simultaneously
  • Image Generation - Support for DALL-E and Stability AI
  • Result Persistence - Save test results with each prompt

Data Security and Privacy

Section titled “Data Security and Privacy”

Your data stays yours:

  • Local-First Storage - All data stored in local SQLite database
  • Master Password Protection - Application-level security
  • Private Folders - Encrypted storage for sensitive prompts (Beta)
  • Full Backup/Restore - Export everything in .phub.gz format
  • WebDAV Sync - Optional cloud sync with services like Nextcloud

Prerequisites and Installation

Section titled “Prerequisites and Installation”

System Requirements

Section titled “System Requirements”

PromptHub runs on:

  • macOS - Intel and Apple Silicon (M1/M2/M3/M4)
  • Windows - x64 architecture
  • Linux - x64 (AppImage and .deb formats)

  2. Review favorites for quick access to common prompts
  3. Use search to find specific prompts by context

Precautions and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions and Troubleshooting”

Common Issues

Section titled “Common Issues”

Application Won’t Start on macOS:

  • Run the xattr command mentioned in installation
  • Check System Settings > Privacy & Security

Database Corruption:

  • Use the backup feature regularly
  • Keep the .phub.gz backup file safe
  • Restore from backup if needed

AI Testing Fails:

  • Verify API key is correct
  • Check API endpoint URL
  • Ensure model name matches provider’s specification

WebDAV Sync Issues:

  • Verify WebDAV URL ends with correct path
  • Test connection in settings before enabling auto-sync
  • Check firewall/proxy settings

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is my data sent to any cloud service? A: No, all data is stored locally. WebDAV sync is optional and user-controlled.

Q: Can I share prompts with colleagues? A: Yes, export individual prompts or full backups in .phub.gz format.

Q: What happens if I forget my master password? A: Unfortunately, encrypted data cannot be recovered without the password.

Q: Does it work offline? A: The prompt management features work fully offline. Only AI testing requires internet.

Claude Code System Prompts Revealed: Inside the AI That Powers Your Coding

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Discover the Hidden Architecture Behind Anthropic’s AI Coding Assistant

The Discovery

Section titled “The Discovery”

Ever wondered what makes Claude Code tick? Thanks to the open-source community, specifically the Piebald-AI/claude-code-system-prompts repository, we now have unprecedented visibility into the intricate system prompts that power one of the most popular AI coding assistants on the market.

This repository, maintained by the team behind Piebald, provides a comprehensive breakdown of all Claude Code’s various system prompts, updated with each new version. As of Claude Code v2.0.75 (December 20th, 2025), it covers 56 versions of changelog since v2.0.14.

Why Claude Code Has Multiple System Prompts

Section titled “Why Claude Code Has Multiple System Prompts”

Claude Code doesn’t just have one single string for its system prompt. Instead, there are multiple components working together:

Component TypeDescription
Conditional PromptsLarge portions added depending on environment and configs
Tool DescriptionsBuiltin tools like Write, Bash, and TodoWrite
Agent PromptsSeparate system prompts for Explore, Plan, and Task agents
Utility FunctionsAI-powered features like conversation compaction, CLAUDE.md generation

The result is 40+ strings that are constantly changing and moving within a very large minified JS file.

Key Prompt Categories

Section titled “Key Prompt Categories”

1. Main System Prompt (2,981 tokens)

Section titled “1. Main System Prompt (2,981 tokens)”

The core system prompt defines Claude Code’s fundamental behavior:

Communication Style:

  • Responses should be “short and concise” for command-line display
  • Uses GitHub-flavored markdown formatted for monospace fonts
  • Avoids emojis unless explicitly requested
  • Tools are for task completion only, not user communication

Technical Approach:

  • Prioritizes technical accuracy and truthfulness
  • Provides direct, objective technical info
  • Reads files before proposing modifications
  • Avoids over-engineering and unnecessary abstractions

2. Agent Prompts

Section titled “2. Agent Prompts”

Sub-agents

Section titled “Sub-agents”
AgentTokensPurpose
Explore516System prompt for the Explore subagent
Plan Mode (Enhanced)633Enhanced prompt for the Plan subagent
Task Tool294System prompt for Task tool spawned subagents

Creation Assistants

Section titled “Creation Assistants”
AgentTokensPurpose
Agent Creation Architect1,111Creating custom AI agents with detailed specifications
CLAUDE.md Creation384Analyzing codebases and creating CLAUDE.md files
Status Line Setup1,310Configuring status line display

3. Slash Commands

Section titled “3. Slash Commands”
CommandTokensPurpose
/pr-comments402Fetching and displaying GitHub PR comments
/review-pr243Reviewing GitHub pull requests

4. Utility Prompts

Section titled “4. Utility Prompts”

Bash Command Prefix Detection835Detecting command prefixes and injection
Conversation Summarization1,121+Creating detailed conversation summaries
Claude Guide Agent763Helping users understand Claude Code
Session Title Generation333Generating titles and git branch names

n8n-skills: Build Flawless n8n Workflows with Claude Code

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Transform Your n8n Workflow Development with AI-Powered Skills

What is n8n-skills?

Section titled “What is n8n-skills?”

n8n-skills is a collection of 7 complementary Claude Code skills designed to teach AI assistants how to build production-ready n8n workflows using the n8n-mcp MCP server.

Created by Romuald Członkowski from AI Advisors, these skills solve the common challenges developers face when building n8n workflows programmatically.

Why n8n-skills Exists

Section titled “Why n8n-skills Exists”

Building n8n workflows programmatically can be challenging. Common issues include:

ChallengeHow n8n-skills Helps
Using MCP tools incorrectlyExpert guidance on tool selection
Validation error loopsValidation error interpretation and fixing
Unknown workflow patterns5 proven architectural patterns
Node misconfigurationOperation-aware node configuration
Expression syntax errorsCorrect {{}} patterns and variables

The 7 Skills

Section titled “The 7 Skills”

1. n8n Expression Syntax

Section titled “1. n8n Expression Syntax”

Teaches correct n8n expression syntax and common patterns.

Activates when: Writing expressions, using {{}} syntax, accessing $json/$node variables.

Key Features:

  • Core variables ($json, $node, $now, $env)
  • Critical gotcha: Webhook data is under $json.body
  • Common mistakes catalog with fixes
  • When NOT to use expressions (Code nodes!)

2. n8n MCP Tools Expert (HIGHEST PRIORITY)

Section titled “2. n8n MCP Tools Expert (HIGHEST PRIORITY)”

Expert guide for using n8n-mcp MCP tools effectively.

Key Features:

  • Tool selection guide (which tool for which task)
  • nodeType format differences (nodes-base.* vs n8n-nodes-base.*)
  • Validation profiles (minimal/runtime/ai-friendly/strict)
  • Smart parameters (branch=“true” for IF nodes)
  • Auto-sanitization system explained

3. n8n Workflow Patterns

Section titled “3. n8n Workflow Patterns”

Build workflows using 5 proven architectural patterns.

  • Pattern selection guide

4. n8n Validation Expert

Section titled “4. n8n Validation Expert”

Interpret validation errors and guide fixing.

  • Validation loop workflow
  • Real error catalog
  • Auto-sanitization behavior explained
  • False positives guide

Operation-aware node configuration guidance.

  • Property dependency rules (e.g., sendBody → contentType)
  • Operation-specific requirements
  • AI connection types (8 types for AI Agent workflows)

6. n8n Code JavaScript

Section titled “6. n8n Code JavaScript”

Write effective JavaScript code in n8n Code nodes.

Key Features:

  • Data access patterns ($input.all(), $input.first(), $input.item)
  • Correct return format: [{json: {...}}]
  • Built-in functions ($helpers.httpRequest(), DateTime, $jmespath())
  • Top 5 error patterns with solutions (covering 62%+ of failures)
  • 10 production-tested patterns

7. n8n Code Python

Section titled “7. n8n Code Python”

Write Python code in n8n Code nodes with proper limitations awareness.

Key Features:

  • Important: Use JavaScript for 95% of use cases
  • Critical limitation: No external libraries (requests, pandas, numpy)
  • Standard library reference (json, datetime, re, etc.)
  • Workarounds for missing libraries

FAQs & Troubleshooting

Section titled “FAQs & Troubleshooting”

Q: Why does my webhook workflow fail?

Section titled “Q: Why does my webhook workflow fail?”

A: Remember that webhook data is under $json.body, not directly in $json. This is the most common gotcha.

Q: How do I choose between Code node JS vs Python?

Section titled “Q: How do I choose between Code node JS vs Python?”

A: Use JavaScript for 95% of use cases. Python has critical limitations:

  • No external libraries (requests, pandas, numpy)
  • Only standard library available

Q: Validation keeps failing with false positives

Section titled “Q: Validation keeps failing with false positives”

A: Use appropriate validation profiles:

  • minimal for quick checks during development
  • runtime for production-ready validation
  • Check the auto-sanitization behavior

Q: Which MCP tools should I use first?

Section titled “Q: Which MCP tools should I use first?”

A: Follow this order:

  1. search_templates - Check if templates exist
  2. search_nodes - Find required nodes
  3. get_node - Get configuration details
  4. validate_node - Validate your config
  5. validate_workflow - Final check
